keyTakeAways: A Portuguese official inquiry has found that a funicular railcar in Lisbon crashed due to a faulty cable, resulting in 16 fatalities and 20 injuries.
The cable did not comply with the specifications required by Lisbon’s transport operator (CCFL) for use on the Gloria tramway, highlighting a violation of safety standards.
The braking system failed to stop the carriage even when activated, indicating a design or mechanical flaw in the safety mechanisms.
The accident occurred on the 19th-century Gloria tramway, a tourist attraction that operates on a counterweight system, which became inoperative after the cable disconnection.
The inquiry recommends that all funiculars in Lisbon remain closed for the foreseeable future until the full safety of the system is confirmed.
The final safety report from the GPIAAF is expected within the next year, with recommendations not yet finalized.

The victims included five Portuguese nationals and 11 foreigners from countries such as the UK, Canada, South Korea, the US, France, Switzerland, and Ukraine, underscoring the international impact of the tragedy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Portuguese inquiry into a fatal crash on the 19th-century Gloria funicular tramway in Lisbon has identified a faulty cable that did not meet safety specifications, leading to a derailment and the deaths of 16 people. The investigation found that the braking system failed to prevent the crash despite being activated, and the tramway’s counterweight system became inoperative after the cable disconnection. As a result, all funiculars in Lisbon are being kept closed for the foreseeable future until a final safety report from the GPIAAF is issued within the next year. The victims included five Portuguese nationals and 11 foreigners from various countries, highlighting the international human toll of the incident.
title: Inquiry recommends Lisbon funicular trams stay closed after September crash
